InstructionsÔÉÅ

We can skip the next cell if neural_de was installed from pip install.

[1]:

import sys
sys.path.append("..")

Let‚Äôs import neural_de

[2]:

from neural_de.transformations import ResolutionEnhancer

We load an example image

[3]:

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from pathlib import Path
import cv2

input_path = Path('../examples/images/fox.jpg')
image = cv2.imread(str(input_path))
image = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB)
plt.imshow(image)
plt.title(image.shape)

[3]:

Text(0.5, 1.0, '(631, 640, 3)')

Enhancing an imageÔÉÅ

We create an instance of ResolutionShift : - If you want to upsample multiple images and have a GPU, it is adviced to install torch with cuda enabled and use device=‚Äôcuda‚Äô, as upsampling can take a lot of time without.

[4]:

shifter = ResolutionEnhancer(device='cpu')

[11-21 11:43:43] {C:\Users\marc.lacourt\PycharmProjects\neuralde\examples\..\neural_de\utils\_twe_logger.py:123} INFO - Logger: name: neural_de_logger, handlers: [<StreamHandler stdout (DEBUG)>]
[11-21 11:43:43] {C:\Users\marc.lacourt\PycharmProjects\neuralde\examples\..\neural_de\transformations\_resolution_enhancer.py:64} INFO - ResolutionEnhancer Initialized

We apply the transform method to any number of images. - we can have multiple images per call of transform, and call transform multiple time with the same shifter. - for now, only ratio=2 is available for upsampling, as the underlaying transformer was trained for a 2x resolution.

[5]:

upsampled = shifter.transform([image], target_shape = (800, 800))

[11-21 11:43:45] {C:\Users\marc.lacourt\PycharmProjects\neuralde\examples\..\neural_de\transformations\_resolution_enhancer.py:73} INFO - Swin2 model loaded to cpu

[6]:

plt.imshow(upsampled[0])
plt.title(upsampled[0].shape)

[6]:

Text(0.5, 1.0, '(800, 800, 3)')

Improving image quality without changing the resolutionÔÉÅ

Using transform with output shape the same as the original image can still improve its quality.

[7]:

improved = shifter.transform([image], target_shape=image.shape[:2])

[8]:

plt.imshow(improved[0])
plt.title(improved[0].shape)

[8]:

Text(0.5, 1.0, '(631, 640, 3)')

Working with batchÔÉÅ

You can provide a batch of image to transform(). - All the images will be resized to target_shape. - It supports images of different sizes as inputs.

[9]:

another_image = image[100:300, 200:450]
improved_images = shifter.transform([image, another_image], target_shape=image.shape[:2])

[10]:

for i in range(2):
    plt.subplot(1,2,i+1)
    plt.imshow(improved_images[i])
    plt.title(improved_images[i].shape)

Include image with a crop ratioÔÉÅ

ratio: foat value in range [0, 1[

[11]:

# crop input image by 70%
improved = shifter.transform([image], target_shape=image.shape[:2], crop_ratio=.7)

plt.imshow(improved[0])
plt.title(improved[0].shape);

[11-21 11:48:06] {C:\Users\marc.lacourt\PycharmProjects\neuralde\examples\..\neural_de\utils\_twe_logger.py:123} INFO - Logger: name: neural_de_logger, handlers: [<StreamHandler stdout (DEBUG)>]
